title: FSM Platform — Field Service Planning
description: A back-office planning platform for a field service team managing technician schedules, routes, territories, and product quantities entirely in Excel — despite already using Dynamics 365 as their CRM. The goal was a dedicated planning tool that integrated with D365 without replacing it.

process.label: Research & workflow mapping
process.text: Sessions with the back-office team to understand how they actually used the spreadsheet — what the Excel columns represented, what workarounds they'd built, and what flexibility they couldn't give up.

process.label: Technical constraints
process.text: Close collaboration with the developer to understand D365 API limits — which data could be read, what could be written back, and where the integration had hard boundaries that had to become design constraints.

process.label: IA & flow definition
process.text: Mapping territories, technician assignments, routes, agendas, stops, and product quantities into a coherent information architecture. The complexity here wasn't technical — it was understanding how these layers related to each other in real operations.

process.label: Design & iteration
process.text: Wireframes → prototype in Figma, tested with back-office operators. The core tension was between structure (needed for consistency) and flexibility (what they relied on in Excel). Resolved by separating fixed logic from flexible views.

keyDecision: Too rigid and operators would work around it; too open and it wouldn't solve anything. The solution was separating fixed logic — territory rules, technician assignments — from flexible views — agenda layout, route planning — so the system enforces what matters without constraining how people move through their day.

title: Codici — Institutional Website
description: An institutional website for Codici Ricerche e Intervento, a social research organization. The project started from scratch with no existing digital presence to build on.

process.label: Stakeholder interviews
process.text: Direct conversations with the client to surface needs, priorities, and desiderata — translating open-ended requests into a defined scope and content structure.

process.label: Competitive review
process.text: Research into comparable organizations' sites to identify conventions, gaps, and opportunities for differentiation within the constraints of an institutional context.

process.label: Wireframes → prototype
process.text: Full UX process in Figma: from low-fidelity wireframes through a fully interactive prototype with UI. Working directly with the client meant managing expectations as much as managing design decisions.

keyDecision: Translating open-ended desiderata into a structure that was clear, maintainable, and appropriate for the organization's communication needs — without over-designing for content that didn't exist yet.

title: Ongoing consultancy — Design System
description: On a second field service management platform, I extended and updated an existing design system — auditing component usage across views, aligning inconsistencies, and redesigning specific screens to match updated product requirements.

process.label: Audit
process.text: Reviewing existing components across all views to identify inconsistencies, outdated patterns, and gaps between the design system and the live product.

process.label: Alignment
process.text: Updating components and documentation to reflect current product requirements, working within existing technical and organizational constraints.

keyDecision: Working within an existing system rather than proposing a redesign — identifying where to intervene minimally for maximum consistency without disrupting what already worked.

title: Design Economy
description:
An editorial publication for Fondazione Symbola and POLI.design, translating economic and cultural data on the Italian design sector into a 120-page report with over 50 data visualizations.

I was responsible for the graphic layout, visual language, and the design of all data visualizations. The main challenge was maintaining narrative coherence across a large volume of heterogeneous data — charts, maps, and infographics had to read consistently while adapting to very different dataset structures.

title: Milano oltre il visibile
description:
A data-driven project exploring Milan through cartographic visualizations that go beyond its institutional narratives — using data and geography to surface less visible urban dynamics.

Working within Propp, I translated structured datasets into maps and visual systems designed to support interpretation rather than direct it. Each visualization required decisions about what to show, what to omit, and how much framing to apply.

title: Antarctic Resolution
description:
An editorial research project treating Antarctica as a geopolitical and environmental system, using data visualization to layer and communicate complex, multi-source information.

As part of a data visualization team at The Pomo, I translated research datasets into publication-ready visuals using RAWGraphs for exploration and Illustrator for refinement. Working within strict editorial constraints required close attention to consistency, accuracy, and visual integration.

title: CFS Lab
description: A digital platform for the Circular Food Systems Lab at Politecnico di Milano — designed as a scalable foundation for a research lab with growing content needs across six sections: home, projects, events, activities, Modulo Design, and Talents in Residence.

process.label: UX & information architecture
process.text: Designing the full structure in Figma — defining how six content sections relate to each other and how the site would scale as content grew.

process.label: Prototype & development
process.text: From fully interactive Figma prototype to WordPress implementation. The current landing page is intentionally structured to grow without requiring a redesign.

keyDecision: Building for future content types and editorial flexibility from the start — the system had to accommodate sections that didn't have content yet without looking incomplete.

title: DiscoJournal
description: A digital platform for a research collective, built to support an editorial format that changes with each annual edition — different themes, different visual languages, same underlying framework. Now in its third edition and actively in use.

process.label: Branding & system design
process.text: Defining a flexible visual and structural system during the initial phase — one that gives each edition room to look and feel distinct while keeping the platform coherent across content-heavy research outputs.

process.label: Three editions, one framework
process.text: The system has supported three editions with different visual languages. The challenge was designing for variation without designing chaos — setting constraints loose enough to allow expression, tight enough to maintain identity.

keyDecision: Designing for variation without designing chaos — setting constraints loose enough to allow expression, tight enough to maintain recognizability across editions.

title: Superforma
description:
A design studio specializing in 3D printing and digital fabrication, active for five years across product design, prototyping, applied research, and education — including over six workshops with an average of five participants each.

As a studio partner, I designed and developed the website, defined the visual identity and social communication, and organized public events and workshops. The work required integrating very different outputs into a single coherent identity that could evolve over time.

title: DoubleCheck
description: An interactive web experience that tests users' ability to recognize manipulated and misleading images online, developed as the final project of Density Design and later released in 22 languages.

process.label: Interaction flow
process.text: Structuring a clear, engaging quiz format that works across very different literacy levels and cultural contexts — without relying on language-specific assumptions.

process.label: Scaling to 22 languages
process.text: Scaling to 22 languages demanded early decisions about layout flexibility, content modularity, and consistency. The UX had to hold up without language-specific assumptions baked into the structure.

keyDecision: Designing a layout flexible enough to accommodate 22 languages — including languages with very different text lengths and reading directions — without reworking the interaction model for each.

title: Data Visualization Works
description:
A collection of data visualization projects developed across different contexts — cartographic and infographic contributions for The Passenger (Iperborea) through Propp, and experimental visualizations exploring algorithmic mediation and data relationships.

Across these projects, the core work is the same: transforming structured datasets into visual forms that are readable, accurate, and open to multiple interpretations. Every decision about what to show, how to encode it, and how much to annotate is also an editorial decision.
